adult.name: Gilt-Mounted Glass Perfume Bottle | London, ca. 1760
adult.description:
This elongated, flat-sided perfume bottle is crafted from cut glass and encased in a frame of gilt metal adorned with swirling foliate scrolls. It features an inner glass stopper and an outer screw-on cap richly decorated with chased floral patterns. Along the rim of the lid, a line of white enamel bears a tender French inscription in gold: “VOTRE AMITIÉ EN RETOUR” — “Your friendship in return.”

Such bottles, celebrated for their abundance of curves and ornate gilt mounts, were fashionable luxury objects in London during the reign of King George III. Portable, intimate, and decorative, they were often exchanged as refined tokens of affection or friendship, carrying not only fragrance but also sentiment.

adult.name: Folding Magnifier | England, ca. 1760–1770
adult.description:
This European-made folding magnifier features a pair of circular lenses that open outward from both sides. The handle is framed with gilt metal carved in flowing floral scrolls, while the central panel is set with polished agate, giving the piece both color and weight. The pierced gold ornamentation reflects the dynamic, symmetrical rhythms of the Baroque style, making this small optical tool as decorative as it is functional.

Such handheld magnifiers were often carried as fashionable accessories in the eighteenth century—objects that blended refinement, curiosity, and the pleasure of close looking.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A slender decorative magnifier with a circular frame at the top and a teardrop-shaped handle below. The handle is filled with a deep blue panel beneath an intricate gilt openwork design of leaves and scrolls. The overall form is elegant, elongated, and richly adorned.

adult.name: Gilt-Mounted Agate Snuffbox | Europe, 18th Century
adult.description:
This rectangular snuffbox opens from the top, revealing a compartment for powdered tobacco. Both the lid and the box are framed with gilt scrolling acanthus designs, within which slices of moss agate are set like miniature picture panels. At the hinge, silver mounts blossom into tiny leaves set with diamonds, rubies, and emeralds, adding a sparkling flourish to the opening gesture.

The underside is similarly framed with gilt decoration and inset with two agate plaques, each concealing an intimate erotic scene—a hidden luxury common in refined snuffboxes of the period. Comparable to another piece in the Museum attributed to James Cox, this box reflects the exquisite craftsmanship of late eighteenth-century England, where mechanical ingenuity and ornamental artistry often met in objects meant to be held, admired, and treasured.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A small rectangular snuffbox framed in gilt metal. Each side and the lid are inset with translucent agate panels featuring soft cloud-like patterns and silhouettes. Delicate gold scrollwork surrounds each stone panel, and the front edge is embellished with a row of small jewels. The box appears symmetrical, refined, and luxurious in detail.

adult.name: Dressing Case | Europe, 18th Century | NPM Enameled Ware 000902
adult.description: This compact dressing case assembles a miniature set of personal grooming tools designed for travel and daily refinement. Such cases typically contain a small mirror, glass bottles for perfumes or aromatic powders, and implements such as knives, scissors, and tweezers. The exterior is often lavishly decorated—its panels inlaid with painted enamel plaques, mother-of-pearl, agate, or multicolored gemstones—capturing the opulent aesthetic of eighteenth-century European craftsmanship. Portable yet sumptuous, these cases reflect a world in which elegance accompanied every gesture, even those performed in private.

kids.name: Tang Dynasty: Sancai Polo Lady Figurine
kids.description: During the Tang dynasty, women admired a healthy and active appearance. They often wore narrow-sleeved jackets with turned-down collars and soft boots—light and practical outfits suitable for various equestrian activities. Polo, introduced from Persia, was especially popular among the upper classes of Tang society, and many tombs have yielded painted pottery or sancai figurines depicting polo players. This piece portrays a fashionable lady engaged in a polo match. She turns her torso to the side, her head leaning slightly forward. Her left hand is raised near the horse’s head as if holding the reins, while her right arm bends as though grasping a stick to strike the ball. A vivid red pigment remains on her chest, indicating the use of precious coloring materials.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Dynasty Sancai Polo Lady Figurine: A ceramic sculpture of a mounted female rider. The composition is balanced, with dominant hues of yellow, green, and brown. The horse stands firmly with legs apart and head slightly lowered. The rider sits upright at the center, with a high coiffed hairstyle and hands positioned as if holding reins. The flowing sancai glazes create a glossy surface, giving the figure a calm and steady presence.

kids.name: Tang Dynasty: Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine
kids.description: Among the mingqi figurines buried as tomb objects in the Tang dynasty, the well-known “Tang sancai” is only one category. Even more numerous—and produced over a longer period—were various types of painted earthenware figurines. These figures were typically molded using red or gray clay, refined by hand, fired in a kiln, and then decorated with painted pigments. In the case of this lady figurine, the piece was first shaped and fired in gray clay, then coated with a layer of white slip, on top of which red, green, black, and other pigments were applied. Unfortunately, most of the original vibrant colors have flaked away over time, leaving only faint traces of its once-brilliant appearance. The National Palace Museum holds two Tang painted gray-earthenware lady figurines (the other catalogued as Gift Porcelain 000550), both made in the Chang’an region during the eighth century and offering a glimpse into contemporary life. Noblewomen in mid-eighth-century Chang’an were characterized by full, rounded faces and elaborate hairstyles extending outward like cicada wings. Their figures were plump and graceful. They wore open-collared jackets and long skirts that grazed the ground, with the pointed tips of embroidered shoes peeking out from beneath. Although the skirt is voluminous, the draping folds of the sleeves and the gathered fabric between the feet reveal the soft, rounded form of the body beneath, fully expressing the elegant confidence and majestic beauty associated with women of the High Tang period.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine: A standing ceramic female figure. She stands upright with arms lowered naturally, one hand slightly raised, her long sleeves forming gentle curves. She wears a long robe with vertical folds falling from the shoulders. Her face is full and rounded with simply defined features and a calm expression. The symmetrical high coiffure is neatly arranged. The overall surface shows a soft, earthy tone with signs of age.

kids.name: Tang Dynasty — Xing Kiln White-Glazed Flask with Strap Loops
kids.description: This white-glazed flask imitates the form of water containers made from metal or leather, often used by nomadic peoples. The exterior walls and base are covered in a glossy white glaze, with pooled areas showing a slight bluish tint reminiscent of lake water. The glaze inside the vessel covers less than half, revealing the grayish-white clay body beneath. The vessel features a flared round mouth, short neck, ring foot, and a long cylindrical body with slightly indented sides. Pairs of strap loops are attached to the upper and lower sections, allowing cords to pass through—much like flasks carried on horseback. During the Tang dynasty, objects made from different materials often imitated one another. Another example in the museum’s collection is a white-glazed molded cup with fish motifs, shaped like a four-petaled flower, which derives from the multi-lobed metal drinking cups of the Sasanian tradition.

medias.alt_text: Tang Dynasty — Xing Kiln White-Glazed Flask with Strap Loops: A smooth, unpainted white ceramic flask. The body is slightly elongated and cylindrical, narrowing toward the top with gently flaring shoulders. The mouth is wide with a simple outward-curving rim. Small, understated strap loops are attached to the upper and lower sections. The flask has a clean, elegant silhouette with a soft white sheen.

kids.name: Five Dynasties — Yue Ware Secret-Color Celadon Basin
kids.description: This celadon basin features an outward-flaring rim with a folded edge, a slanted curved wall, deep rounded belly, and a flat base. The center of the underside is slightly concave, and firing marks remain clearly visible along the footring, where the unglazed areas reveal the gray clay body. The piece is covered in a translucent celadon glaze of grayish-green tone. The glaze is thin and evenly applied, with a few pale speckled patches on the outer wall. Before archaeological discoveries in the early Republic of China period clarified kiln attributions, experts from the Qing Court Aftercare Committee mistakenly identified this piece as a Ru ware product and inscribed inside the basin: “One Ru ware flared-rim fruit wash.” This inscription reflects how historical and modern approaches to ceramic connoisseurship may differ. The museum’s Yue ware ‘secret-color’ celadon basin is finely glazed, elegant in form, and closely resembles celadon basins unearthed from Five Dynasties tombs, suggesting it may have been used by members of the upper class during that period.

kids.name: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Baby Pillow
kids.description: This white-glazed ceramic pillow shaped as a reclining infant exemplifies the refined modeling and decorative techniques of Ding ware. Ding kilns primarily produced white porcelains noted for their precise craftsmanship, smooth and lustrous glaze, and ivory-tinged color. Decorative methods included shallow carving, deep engraving, and molded designs. On this pillow, the creamy white glaze appears warm and mellow. The head and body were each formed in two joined halves, assembled together, and then finely carved to define the facial features. Various decorative techniques were skillfully combined: the floral motifs along the hem of the long garment, the spherical patterns on the vest, and the cloud-and-chilong designs on the platform are all rendered through molding, while the peony scrolls on the back are carved. The molded patterns are crisp, and the carved lines flow naturally, achieving a harmonious balance. On the underside is an imperial poem composed by the Qianlong Emperor, in which he likens such pillows to ‘warning pillows’—objects reminding him to remain diligent. When read together with other imperial poems on Ding ware child pillows, it also reveals his wish, like King Wu Ding in ancient times, to find virtuous ministers through dreams. Only three surviving examples of this baby-pillow form are known today, two housed in this museum and the third in the Palace Museum, Beijing.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Baby Pillow: A ceramic figure of an infant lying sideways on a rectangular platform. The child lifts its head slightly, with both hands resting beneath the cheek. The rounded face shows a calm, gentle smile. The clothing bears delicate patterns, with folds and motifs clearly rendered. The glaze is soft and pale, with a smooth, ivory-white sheen.

kids.name: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Meiping with Incised Lotus Design
kids.description: This meiping vase features a small mouth with a rounded lip, a short neck, high rounded shoulders, and an elongated body that tapers gracefully downward before flaring slightly near the base. The recessed base forms a ring foot. The vessel is decorated with incised motifs. Short, oval lotus petals are arranged in rows around the upper section, while the lower section features slender, elongated petals outlined with double incised lines. At the center of the body, front and back, appear sprays of branching lotus blossoms, accompanied on each side by simple outlines of lotus leaves. The entire vase is covered in an ivory-white glaze that drips lightly in places, forming characteristic tear marks. The footrim is left unglazed.

The glaze is soft and creamy white, giving the vase an elegant, elongated form.

kids.name: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Zun with String-Pattern Decoration
kids.description: This vessel features a cylindrical body with straight sides, an inner rim forming a raised lip, deep vertical walls, and three beast-shaped feet left unglazed on the underside. The form is stately and balanced, with a rich bluish-green glaze characteristic of Guan ware. The dense network of crackles appears in layered patterns, while the shape itself derives from earlier Northern Song forms seen in Ru and Ding ware zun vessels with string-pattern bands. The broad and flat base bears twelve large spur marks revealing the dark gray clay body beneath. The exterior wall is decorated with three tiers of string patterns, each composed of three horizontal raised lines. The entire piece is coated in a thick, lustrous pale blue glaze. Where the glaze pools and thins around the ridges, the string-pattern relief appears slightly darkened in brownish tones. Along the rim, the thinner glaze reveals subtle reddish-brown hues. The surface is covered in intricate, ice-crackle patterns. Similar fragments have been unearthed at the Jiaotanxia and Laohudong Guan kiln sites in Hangzhou, Zhejiang.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Zun with String-Pattern Decoration: A circular vessel shown upside down. The pale celadon glaze displays dense crackle patterns. Multiple pronounced spur marks appear across the base, in dark brown tones. Three short supporting feet of matching glaze emerge around the edge, giving the object a stable, disc-like appearance.

audio_files.transcript: This vessel features a cylindrical body with straight sides, an inner rim forming a raised lip, deep vertical walls, and three beast-shaped feet left unglazed on the underside. The form is stately and balanced, with a rich bluish-green glaze characteristic of Guan ware. The dense network of crackles appears in layered patterns, while the shape itself derives from earlier Northern Song forms seen in Ru and Ding ware zun vessels with string-pattern bands. The broad and flat base bears twelve large spur marks revealing the dark gray clay body beneath. The exterior wall is decorated with three tiers of string patterns, each composed of three horizontal raised lines. The entire piece is coated in a thick, lustrous pale blue glaze. Where the glaze pools and thins around the ridges, the string-pattern relief appears slightly darkened in brownish tones. Along the rim, the thinner glaze reveals subtle reddish-brown hues. The surface is covered in intricate, ice-crackle patterns. Similar fragments have been unearthed at the Jiaotanxia and Laohudong Guan kiln sites in Hangzhou, Zhejiang.

kids.name: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Vase with Tube Handles
kids.description: This vase features a slightly flared round mouth, a short neck, and a pair of tubular handles attached symmetrically to the shoulders. The body is full and rounded, tapering to a flat base supported by a low ring foot. Two raised string lines encircle the neck. The clay body is thick and substantial, and the entire vessel is coated in a rich celadon glaze. The surface is covered with fine crackle lines in pale brown tones, with occasional tiny pinholes. The edge of the ring foot reveals the unglazed clay body, brushed with an iron-brown slip.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Vase with Tube Handles: A pale celadon-glazed vase with a rounded body, narrow neck, and flared rim. The surface is covered in fine crackle patterns. Two short tubular handles extend symmetrically from the shoulders. The foot flares gently outward to form a stable circular base. The overall shape is harmonious and understated.

kids.name: Song Dynasty — Jian Ware Black-Glazed “Hare’s Fur” Tea Bowl
kids.description: This tea bowl features a contracted rim with a gently inward-curving lip, deep rounded walls, and a small ring foot. The glaze does not extend to the base, leaving the thick, coarse, dark brown clay exposed. The exterior of the foot is unglazed, while the recessed inner foot bears an incised character, 律 (“lü”), in regular script. The glaze is a dense, flowing jet-black that drips down the outer wall near the foot and pools thickly at the interior center. Around the rim, the thinner glaze forms the characteristic warm brown “hare’s fur mouth.” Both the interior and exterior surfaces display fine streaks of blue-yellow crystalline patterns created during firing. These streaks flow with the glaze, interweaving in rich layers reminiscent of the glossy fur of an autumn hare—hence the name “hare’s fur bowl,” as used in the Song dynasty.

kids.name: Southern Song Dynasty — Longquan Celadon Vase with Phoenix Handles
kids.description: This celadon vase features a straight body, long neck, and dish-shaped mouth. Phoenix-shaped handles are applied to both sides of the neck, giving the piece an elegant and dignified silhouette. It is one of the representative works of the Longquan kilns during the Southern Song dynasty. Located in southern Zhejiang, Longquan was a vast ceramic-production region known for its diverse output. After the Southern Song period, it became a major supplier of ceramics both domestically and internationally, with its wares frequently discovered in Song and Yuan tombs, hoards, and archaeological sites along overseas trade routes. The long-necked, dish-lipped vase type was first produced by the Northern Song Ru kilns and later adopted by Southern Song official kilns, becoming a favored form among imperial ceramics. Longquan potters then introduced variations by adding fish- or phoenix-shaped handles. On this vase, the phoenix handles are crisply molded, with clearly defined heads and feathers. The glaze is a luminous powder-green celadon, smooth, even, and free of flaws. It closely resembles the celebrated Longquan phoenix-ear vases preserved in Japan, inscribed by imperial decree with the names “Senshō” and “Banshō,” and ranks among the finest examples of Longquan ware.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Southern Song Dynasty Longquan Celadon Phoenix-Ear Vase: A pale green celadon vase with a straight, symmetrical form. The cylindrical lower body transitions into a long neck and wide flat mouth. Decorative phoenix-shaped handles appear on both sides. The glaze is smooth and evenly applied.

kids.name: Yuan Dynasty — Cobalt-Blue Cup with Single Handle
kids.description: This cup has a funnel-shaped form with a metal rim at the mouth. The slanted body features a ring-shaped handle on one side. The base is carved into a recessed foot, left unglazed and coated with a yellowish-brown slip for protection. Except for the base, the entire surface is covered in a cobalt-blue glaze. Traces of once-present gold or silver foil decoration can still be faintly seen on the glaze. Below the inner rim is a band of lozenge-patterned squares, while the center of the interior displays a twelve-pointed star rosette. A single branch of plum blossoms encircles the exterior wall.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Yuan Dynasty Cobalt-Blue Single-Handled Cup: A deep-blue, funnel-shaped cup with a slightly flared rim edged in metal. One side features a small rectangular loop handle. The glaze is smooth and richly colored.

kids.name: Yuan Dynasty — Jun Ware Bowl with Sky-Blue Glaze and Purple Splashes
kids.description: This bowl features a slightly constricted, round mouth, deep curving walls, and a pointed base with a short ring foot. The glaze differs between the interior and exterior. Inside, the glaze is a sky-blue color, with the unglazed area at the base center showing a three-pronged support mark. The exterior is also sky-blue but displays cloud-like purple splashes within the glaze layer, resembling rosy clouds. The rim is accented with a band of reddish-brown. Parts of the ring foot are roughly finished, and the unglazed areas on the foot base, foot wall, and inner rim reveal the reddish earthen body. The slightly convex base is coated with sky-blue glaze.

kids.name: Memorial to the Throne Requesting Imperial Well-being and Reporting Audiences with Cao Yin, Superintendent of the Jiangning Imperial Weaving Office
kids.description:
Dated July 29, 1704 (the 43rd year of the Kangxi reign, Qing dynasty)
National Palace Museum catalog no. 002712
Height: 20.5 cm; Width: 48.2 cm

The phrase “a family of poetry, ritual, and noble rank” refers to aristocratic households devoted to classical learning and Confucian etiquette across generations. Cao Xueqin, author of *Dream of the Red Chamber*, was born into such a distinguished literary family. His grandfather, Cao Yin, excelled in poetry and textual collations, and was commissioned to edit the *Imperially Commissioned Complete Tang Poems*. Beginning with Cao Yin’s grandfather, Cao Xi, the Cao family held—over three generations and four appointments—the prestigious post of Jiangning Imperial Weaving Superintendent. This position, entrusted only to those close to the emperor, was responsible for producing and procuring textiles and items required by the imperial household, including the silk robes for the *Dragon Canon*.

These unique life experiences profoundly shaped Cao Xueqin. The refined poetry, elegant musical compositions, and exquisite descriptions of objects found throughout *Dream of the Red Chamber* reflect the cultural richness and material sophistication inherited from his family background.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Memorial to the Throne by Cao Yin, Superintendent of the Jiangning Imperial Weaving Office: A horizontal scroll composed mainly of written text. Black characters arranged vertically from right to left dominate the composition. A column of red ink text appears beside them, with a small red seal stamped at the far left. The layout is simple with generous blank space.

kids.name: Illustrated Poems of *Dream of the Red Chamber*
kids.description:
Written by Gai Qi, Qing dynasty
Illustrated woodblock-printed book, published in the 5th year of the Guangxu reign (1879)
National Palace Museum catalog nos. 003571—003574
Height: 22.5 cm; Width: 15 cm

Much about Cao Xueqin remains shrouded in mystery. After the Cao family fell from power and its property was confiscated, Cao Xueqin—overwhelmed by sorrow—returned to Beijing. In 1762, on New Year's Eve of the renwu year (the 27th year of the Qianlong reign), he passed away “before reaching the age of fifty, his tears exhausted while the book remained unfinished.” Our understanding of his short life and his incomplete *Dream of the Red Chamber* is often fragmentary, as if his very existence were a riddle.

Yet the novel’s unfinished state has never diminished its allure. If anything, its open-endedness inspired generations of readers, giving rise to numerous editions, commentaries, and pictorial interpretations such as this illustrated work.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Illustrated Poems of Dream of the Red Chamber: A book cover design featuring a fine-line drawing of two figures in traditional attire standing beside a large rock. To the right runs a vertical title strip with black characters framed by decorative triangular corners. The layout clearly separates the illustration on the left from the title panel on the right.

kids.name: Gold Headdress Finial Set with Eastern Pearls and Cat’s-Eye Stone for an Imperial Consort, Qing dynasty, Qianlong reign
kids.description:
NPM collection no. 4837
Height: 16 cm; Base diameter: 4.8 cm

Yuanfei, whose formal name is Jia Yuanchun, is the elder sister of Jia Baoyu. Entering the palace at the age of thirteen or fourteen, she later rose to the rank of Imperial Consort, bringing the Jia family to the height of its glory. The practice of "returning home to observe filial piety" allowed imperial consorts to leave the palace temporarily to visit their parents and elders. To welcome Yuanchun on such an occasion, the Jia family constructed the Grand View Garden.

The Grand View Garden becomes many things at once: a fleeting paradise where Yuanchun briefly reunites with her family yet remains forever separated from her youth; a secluded world where Baoyu and the young maidens live under the protective shadow of her imperial status; and, ultimately, a lost eden—Cao Xueqin’s elegy for a bygone age of prosperity and tenderness.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Qianlong-period gold headdress finial with layered openwork design; the hemispherical gold base is adorned with intricate patterns, supporting multiple tiers of curled and pierced gold elements in bird and foliage motifs. Set with round Eastern pearls throughout, topped by an oval cat’s-eye gemstone of warm yellow-brown hue.

kids.name: Bronze Censer, Vase, and Box with Gui Motifs, Late Ming to Qing dynasty
kids.description:
NPM collection nos. 1565, 1820, 1819
Censer height: 15 cm; Vase height: 13.8 cm; Box height: 7.9 cm

A faint thread of fragrance seems to drift through every page of *Dream of the Red Chamber*. Incense is burned not only in grand ceremonies, but also during the Jia household’s daily routines. When the Imperial Consort Yuanchun returns home for her ceremonial visit, lilies are burned in great braziers throughout the Grand View Garden. At family banquets, the Jia clan sets out the elegant trio of censer, vase, and box on the table, using them to burn the imperial “Lily Palace Incense.”

This set of three—censer, incense box, and utensil vase—forms a complete ensemble. The censer is used for burning incense; the box stores incense; and the vase holds tools such as tongs and scoops. Arranged with the censer in the center and the box and vase to either side, the censer takes pride of place. The censer mentioned in the novel, known as the *Wenwang ding*, derives from bronze ritual vessels used in ceremonies honoring King Wen of Zhou. Frequently imitated in the Ming and Qing periods, such archaistic pieces were treasured as refined objects suited to the contemplative atmosphere of the scholar’s studio.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Bronze censer, vase, and box set on a carved wooden stand. The vase at left has a slender neck and holds incense tools; the central tripod censer features gilded surfaces with blue-green geometric bands; and the round lidded box at right displays matching decoration. The three pieces form a ritual-like arrangement reminiscent of traditional incense sets.

kids.name: In the Style of the Song: Ru Ware and Ding Ware
kids.description:
NPM collection no. 17854
Mouth diameter: 15.7 cm; Height: 3.7 cm

Porcelain used in everyday life throughout *Dream of the Red Chamber* frequently evokes the celebrated kilns of the Song dynasty—Ru ware and Ding ware—as well as renowned imperial kilns of the Ming, such as Xuande and Chenghua. These refined objects embellish both the Jia household and the Grand View Garden. For Cao Xueqin, such elegance was embedded in memory: exquisite antique ceramics, alongside Qing-period archaistic wares, form the backdrop of the world he reimagined.

Ru ware—“as precious as the morning star”—appears repeatedly in the novel in the form of dishes, vases, and flower vessels. Ding ware—“the finest white under heaven”—is likewise present: at Baoyu’s birthday banquet, forty Ding ware dishes are used to serve delicacies and seasonal fruits. Quietly luxurious yet understated, these porcelains leave a lasting impression of the refined daily life they once adorned.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A shallow circular dish coated in a soft bluish-grey glaze. The surface is covered with fine crackle patterns, and the gently rounded rim and neatly carved foot give the piece an elegant, understated presence characteristic of Song-inspired ware.

kids.name: Clock | William Carpenter, London (1770–1805) | NPM Collection No. 726
kids.description:
This ornate clock features a circular dial with Roman numerals for the hours and Arabic numerals marking the minutes and seconds. Encircled by radiant sunburst ornamentation, the face is protected beneath an oval glass cover. The oval case itself is bordered with petal-like motifs, while the top is embellished with a quiver of arrows, a torch, and fluttering ribbons—classical symbols of enlightenment and refined taste.

Below, scrolling acanthus leaves support the clock, which stands on a two-tiered base: the upper platform rests on four eagle-shaped feet, and the lower tier is adorned with floral designs. On the reverse appears the inscription “Willm Carpenter London,” along with a scale regulating speed—“FASTER,” “1–9,” “SLOWER.” Two original winding keys accompany the piece.

Elegant, intricate, and richly symbolic, the clock reflects the craftsmanship and decorative vocabulary of late eighteenth-century London, embodying both precision timekeeping and the aesthetic ideals of its age.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: An ornate gold-colored mantel clock with an oval case. The white dial displays Roman numerals and is surrounded by sunburst rays. Decorative motifs—including ribbons, foliage, and scrolls—adorn the top and base, which rests on intricately formed feet. The overall design is lavish and highly detailed.

kids.name: Porcelain Sugar Bowl | Sèvres Manufactory, France, 1783
kids.description:
This luminous sugar bowl—its white glaze adorned with delicate gold decoration—bears traces of a long and distinguished journey. On its underside remain both the Sèvres factory marks and an original retail label, preserving the story of how it was made, sold, and eventually carried across continents.

At the center of its marks is the pair of crossed “L”s, the emblem used by the Sèvres manufactory in honor of the French kings Louis XIV and Louis XV. Inside the intertwined letters appears a small double “f,” a date letter indicating the year of manufacture. By comparing this mark to factory records, the bowl can be firmly dated to 1783—placing it within the reign of Louis XV, as the crossed “L”s here suggest.

In its early years Sèvres could produce only soft-paste porcelain, but by the 1770s the factory had finally mastered hard-paste—considered in Europe the equal of prized Chinese porcelain. The gilded crown painted above the mark is the factory’s proud signifier of true hard-paste ware. The initials “LF” at the bottom identify the decorator, the skilled painter La France, who in the spring of 1783 embellished not only this bowl but also matching teapots, milk jugs, and cups with the same refined motifs.

During the latter half of the eighteenth century, Sèvres was overseen by France’s prime minister, Henry Leonard Jean-Baptiste Bertin, a statesman deeply fascinated by distant China. Hoping to express goodwill toward the Qianlong Emperor, Bertin purchased this sugar bowl for 18 livres and arranged for it to be delivered across great distance to the Qing court. The surviving retail label—still legible today—quietly preserves this once-forgotten story of diplomacy, craftsmanship, and the global travels of a single porcelain piece.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A white porcelain sugar bowl decorated with fine gilded floral patterns. The rounded body and matching lid are accented with gold detailing, including a small gilded knop at the top. Elegant, restrained, and luminous in contrast between white glaze and gold lines.

kids.name: Gilt-Mounted Glass Perfume Bottle | London, ca. 1760
kids.description:
This elongated, flat-sided perfume bottle is crafted from cut glass and encased in a frame of gilt metal adorned with swirling foliate scrolls. It features an inner glass stopper and an outer screw-on cap richly decorated with chased floral patterns. Along the rim of the lid, a line of white enamel bears a tender French inscription in gold: “VOTRE AMITIÉ EN RETOUR” — “Your friendship in return.”

Such bottles, celebrated for their abundance of curves and ornate gilt mounts, were fashionable luxury objects in London during the reign of King George III. Portable, intimate, and decorative, they were often exchanged as refined tokens of affection or friendship, carrying not only fragrance but also sentiment.

kids.name: Folding Magnifier | England, ca. 1760–1770
kids.description:
This European-made folding magnifier features a pair of circular lenses that open outward from both sides. The handle is framed with gilt metal carved in flowing floral scrolls, while the central panel is set with polished agate, giving the piece both color and weight. The pierced gold ornamentation reflects the dynamic, symmetrical rhythms of the Baroque style, making this small optical tool as decorative as it is functional.

Such handheld magnifiers were often carried as fashionable accessories in the eighteenth century—objects that blended refinement, curiosity, and the pleasure of close looking.

kids.name: Gilt-Mounted Agate Snuffbox | Europe, 18th Century
kids.description:
This rectangular snuffbox opens from the top, revealing a compartment for powdered tobacco. Both the lid and the box are framed with gilt scrolling acanthus designs, within which slices of moss agate are set like miniature picture panels. At the hinge, silver mounts blossom into tiny leaves set with diamonds, rubies, and emeralds, adding a sparkling flourish to the opening gesture.

The underside is similarly framed with gilt decoration and inset with two agate plaques, each concealing an intimate erotic scene—a hidden luxury common in refined snuffboxes of the period. Comparable to another piece in the Museum attributed to James Cox, this box reflects the exquisite craftsmanship of late eighteenth-century England, where mechanical ingenuity and ornamental artistry often met in objects meant to be held, admired, and treasured.

Delicate gold scrollwork surrounds each stone panel, and the front edge is embellished with a row of small jewels. The box appears symmetrical, refined, and luxurious in detail.

Portable yet sumptuous, these cases reflect a world in which elegance accompanied every gesture, even those performed in private.

sign_language.name: Tang Dynasty: Sancai Polo Lady Figurine
sign_language.description: During the Tang dynasty, women admired a healthy and active appearance. They often wore narrow-sleeved jackets with turned-down collars and soft boots—light and practical outfits suitable for various equestrian activities. Polo, introduced from Persia, was especially popular among the upper classes of Tang society, and many tombs have yielded painted pottery or sancai figurines depicting polo players. This piece portrays a fashionable lady engaged in a polo match. She turns her torso to the side, her head leaning slightly forward. Her left hand is raised near the horse’s head as if holding the reins, while her right arm bends as though grasping a stick to strike the ball. A vivid red pigment remains on her chest, indicating the use of precious coloring materials.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Dynasty Sancai Polo Lady Figurine: A ceramic sculpture of a mounted female rider. The composition is balanced, with dominant hues of yellow, green, and brown. The horse stands firmly with legs apart and head slightly lowered. The rider sits upright at the center, with a high coiffed hairstyle and hands positioned as if holding reins. The flowing sancai glazes create a glossy surface, giving the figure a calm and steady presence.

sign_language.name: Tang Dynasty: Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine
sign_language.description: Among the mingqi figurines buried as tomb objects in the Tang dynasty, the well-known “Tang sancai” is only one category. Even more numerous—and produced over a longer period—were various types of painted earthenware figurines. These figures were typically molded using red or gray clay, refined by hand, fired in a kiln, and then decorated with painted pigments. In the case of this lady figurine, the piece was first shaped and fired in gray clay, then coated with a layer of white slip, on top of which red, green, black, and other pigments were applied. Unfortunately, most of the original vibrant colors have flaked away over time, leaving only faint traces of its once-brilliant appearance. The National Palace Museum holds two Tang painted gray-earthenware lady figurines (the other catalogued as Gift Porcelain 000550), both made in the Chang’an region during the eighth century and offering a glimpse into contemporary life. Noblewomen in mid-eighth-century Chang’an were characterized by full, rounded faces and elaborate hairstyles extending outward like cicada wings. Their figures were plump and graceful. They wore open-collared jackets and long skirts that grazed the ground, with the pointed tips of embroidered shoes peeking out from beneath. Although the skirt is voluminous, the draping folds of the sleeves and the gathered fabric between the feet reveal the soft, rounded form of the body beneath, fully expressing the elegant confidence and majestic beauty associated with women of the High Tang period.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine: A standing ceramic female figure. She stands upright with arms lowered naturally, one hand slightly raised, her long sleeves forming gentle curves. She wears a long robe with vertical folds falling from the shoulders. Her face is full and rounded with simply defined features and a calm expression. The symmetrical high coiffure is neatly arranged. The overall surface shows a soft, earthy tone with signs of age.

sign_language.name: Tang Dynasty — Xing Kiln White-Glazed Flask with Strap Loops
sign_language.description: This white-glazed flask imitates the form of water containers made from metal or leather, often used by nomadic peoples. The exterior walls and base are covered in a glossy white glaze, with pooled areas showing a slight bluish tint reminiscent of lake water. The glaze inside the vessel covers less than half, revealing the grayish-white clay body beneath. The vessel features a flared round mouth, short neck, ring foot, and a long cylindrical body with slightly indented sides. Pairs of strap loops are attached to the upper and lower sections, allowing cords to pass through—much like flasks carried on horseback. During the Tang dynasty, objects made from different materials often imitated one another. Another example in the museum’s collection is a white-glazed molded cup with fish motifs, shaped like a four-petaled flower, which derives from the multi-lobed metal drinking cups of the Sasanian tradition.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Dynasty — Xing Kiln White-Glazed Flask with Strap Loops: A smooth, unpainted white ceramic flask. The body is slightly elongated and cylindrical, narrowing toward the top with gently flaring shoulders. The mouth is wide with a simple outward-curving rim. Small, understated strap loops are attached to the upper and lower sections. The flask has a clean, elegant silhouette with a soft white sheen.

sign_language.name: Five Dynasties — Yue Ware Secret-Color Celadon Basin
sign_language.description: This celadon basin features an outward-flaring rim with a folded edge, a slanted curved wall, deep rounded belly, and a flat base. The center of the underside is slightly concave, and firing marks remain clearly visible along the footring, where the unglazed areas reveal the gray clay body. The piece is covered in a translucent celadon glaze of grayish-green tone. The glaze is thin and evenly applied, with a few pale speckled patches on the outer wall. Before archaeological discoveries in the early Republic of China period clarified kiln attributions, experts from the Qing Court Aftercare Committee mistakenly identified this piece as a Ru ware product and inscribed inside the basin: “One Ru ware flared-rim fruit wash.” This inscription reflects how historical and modern approaches to ceramic connoisseurship may differ. The museum’s Yue ware ‘secret-color’ celadon basin is finely glazed, elegant in form, and closely resembles celadon basins unearthed from Five Dynasties tombs, suggesting it may have been used by members of the upper class during that period.

Covered in a soft greenish celadon glaze, the surface is even with subtle natural speckling. The body tapers downward toward a smaller flat base, giving the vessel a simple and composed appearance.

sign_language.name: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Baby Pillow
sign_language.description: This white-glazed ceramic pillow shaped as a reclining infant exemplifies the refined modeling and decorative techniques of Ding ware. Ding kilns primarily produced white porcelains noted for their precise craftsmanship, smooth and lustrous glaze, and ivory-tinged color. Decorative methods included shallow carving, deep engraving, and molded designs. On this pillow, the creamy white glaze appears warm and mellow. The head and body were each formed in two joined halves, assembled together, and then finely carved to define the facial features. Various decorative techniques were skillfully combined: the floral motifs along the hem of the long garment, the spherical patterns on the vest, and the cloud-and-chilong designs on the platform are all rendered through molding, while the peony scrolls on the back are carved. The molded patterns are crisp, and the carved lines flow naturally, achieving a harmonious balance. On the underside is an imperial poem composed by the Qianlong Emperor, in which he likens such pillows to ‘warning pillows’—objects reminding him to remain diligent. When read together with other imperial poems on Ding ware child pillows, it also reveals his wish, like King Wu Ding in ancient times, to find virtuous ministers through dreams. Only three surviving examples of this baby-pillow form are known today, two housed in this museum and the third in the Palace Museum, Beijing.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Baby Pillow: A ceramic figure of an infant lying sideways on a rectangular platform. The child lifts its head slightly, with both hands resting beneath the cheek. The rounded face shows a calm, gentle smile. The clothing bears delicate patterns, with folds and motifs clearly rendered. The glaze is soft and pale, with a smooth, ivory-white sheen.

sign_language.name: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Meiping with Incised Lotus Design
sign_language.description: This meiping vase features a small mouth with a rounded lip, a short neck, high rounded shoulders, and an elongated body that tapers gracefully downward before flaring slightly near the base. The recessed base forms a ring foot. The vessel is decorated with incised motifs. Short, oval lotus petals are arranged in rows around the upper section, while the lower section features slender, elongated petals outlined with double incised lines. At the center of the body, front and back, appear sprays of branching lotus blossoms, accompanied on each side by simple outlines of lotus leaves. The entire vase is covered in an ivory-white glaze that drips lightly in places, forming characteristic tear marks. The footrim is left unglazed.

medias.alt_text: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Meiping with Incised Lotus Design: A tall white porcelain vase with a gently curving silhouette that tapers toward the base. The glaze is soft and creamy white, giving the vase an elegant, elongated form.

sign_language.name: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Zun with String-Pattern Decoration
sign_language.description: This vessel features a cylindrical body with straight sides, an inner rim forming a raised lip, deep vertical walls, and three beast-shaped feet left unglazed on the underside. The form is stately and balanced, with a rich bluish-green glaze characteristic of Guan ware. The dense network of crackles appears in layered patterns, while the shape itself derives from earlier Northern Song forms seen in Ru and Ding ware zun vessels with string-pattern bands. The broad and flat base bears twelve large spur marks revealing the dark gray clay body beneath. The exterior wall is decorated with three tiers of string patterns, each composed of three horizontal raised lines. The entire piece is coated in a thick, lustrous pale blue glaze. Where the glaze pools and thins around the ridges, the string-pattern relief appears slightly darkened in brownish tones. Along the rim, the thinner glaze reveals subtle reddish-brown hues. The surface is covered in intricate, ice-crackle patterns. Similar fragments have been unearthed at the Jiaotanxia and Laohudong Guan kiln sites in Hangzhou, Zhejiang.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Zun with String-Pattern Decoration: A circular vessel shown upside down. The pale celadon glaze displays dense crackle patterns. Multiple pronounced spur marks appear across the base, in dark brown tones. Three short supporting feet of matching glaze emerge around the edge, giving the object a stable, disc-like appearance.

sign_language.name: Song Dynasty — Jian Ware Black-Glazed “Hare’s Fur” Tea Bowl
sign_language.description: This tea bowl features a contracted rim with a gently inward-curving lip, deep rounded walls, and a small ring foot. The glaze does not extend to the base, leaving the thick, coarse, dark brown clay exposed. The exterior of the foot is unglazed, while the recessed inner foot bears an incised character, 律 (“lü”), in regular script. The glaze is a dense, flowing jet-black that drips down the outer wall near the foot and pools thickly at the interior center. Around the rim, the thinner glaze forms the characteristic warm brown “hare’s fur mouth.” Both the interior and exterior surfaces display fine streaks of blue-yellow crystalline patterns created during firing. These streaks flow with the glaze, interweaving in rich layers reminiscent of the glossy fur of an autumn hare—hence the name “hare’s fur bowl,” as used in the Song dynasty.

sign_language.name: Southern Song Dynasty — Longquan Celadon Vase with Phoenix Handles
sign_language.description: This celadon vase features a straight body, long neck, and dish-shaped mouth. Phoenix-shaped handles are applied to both sides of the neck, giving the piece an elegant and dignified silhouette. It is one of the representative works of the Longquan kilns during the Southern Song dynasty. Located in southern Zhejiang, Longquan was a vast ceramic-production region known for its diverse output. After the Southern Song period, it became a major supplier of ceramics both domestically and internationally, with its wares frequently discovered in Song and Yuan tombs, hoards, and archaeological sites along overseas trade routes. The long-necked, dish-lipped vase type was first produced by the Northern Song Ru kilns and later adopted by Southern Song official kilns, becoming a favored form among imperial ceramics. Longquan potters then introduced variations by adding fish- or phoenix-shaped handles. On this vase, the phoenix handles are crisply molded, with clearly defined heads and feathers. The glaze is a luminous powder-green celadon, smooth, even, and free of flaws. It closely resembles the celebrated Longquan phoenix-ear vases preserved in Japan, inscribed by imperial decree with the names “Senshō” and “Banshō,” and ranks among the finest examples of Longquan ware.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Southern Song Dynasty Longquan Celadon Phoenix-Ear Vase: A pale green celadon vase with a straight, symmetrical form. The cylindrical lower body transitions into a long neck and wide flat mouth. Decorative phoenix-shaped handles appear on both sides. The glaze is smooth and evenly applied.

sign_language.name: Yuan Dynasty — Cobalt-Blue Cup with Single Handle
sign_language.description: This cup has a funnel-shaped form with a metal rim at the mouth. The slanted body features a ring-shaped handle on one side. The base is carved into a recessed foot, left unglazed and coated with a yellowish-brown slip for protection. Except for the base, the entire surface is covered in a cobalt-blue glaze. Traces of once-present gold or silver foil decoration can still be faintly seen on the glaze. Below the inner rim is a band of lozenge-patterned squares, while the center of the interior displays a twelve-pointed star rosette. A single branch of plum blossoms encircles the exterior wall.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Yuan Dynasty Cobalt-Blue Single-Handled Cup: A deep-blue, funnel-shaped cup with a slightly flared rim edged in metal. One side features a small rectangular loop handle. The glaze is smooth and richly colored.

sign_language.name: Yuan Dynasty — Jun Ware Bowl with Sky-Blue Glaze and Purple Splashes
sign_language.description: This bowl features a slightly constricted, round mouth, deep curving walls, and a pointed base with a short ring foot. The glaze differs between the interior and exterior. Inside, the glaze is a sky-blue color, with the unglazed area at the base center showing a three-pronged support mark. The exterior is also sky-blue but displays cloud-like purple splashes within the glaze layer, resembling rosy clouds. The rim is accented with a band of reddish-brown. Parts of the ring foot are roughly finished, and the unglazed areas on the foot base, foot wall, and inner rim reveal the reddish earthen body. The slightly convex base is coated with sky-blue glaze.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Yuan Dynasty Jun Ware Bowl with Sky-Blue Glaze and Purple Splashes: A round ceramic bowl featuring soft gradient hues blending light blue, violet, and green. The rim slightly flares outward with a fine brown edge. The body is full and rounded with a small circular foot.

sign_language.name: Memorial to the Throne Requesting Imperial Well-being and Reporting Audiences with Cao Yin, Superintendent of the Jiangning Imperial Weaving Office
sign_language.description:
Dated July 29, 1704 (the 43rd year of the Kangxi reign, Qing dynasty)
National Palace Museum catalog no. 002712
Height: 20.5 cm; Width: 48.2 cm

The phrase “a family of poetry, ritual, and noble rank” refers to aristocratic households devoted to classical learning and Confucian etiquette across generations. Cao Xueqin, author of *Dream of the Red Chamber*, was born into such a distinguished literary family. His grandfather, Cao Yin, excelled in poetry and textual collations, and was commissioned to edit the *Imperially Commissioned Complete Tang Poems*. Beginning with Cao Yin’s grandfather, Cao Xi, the Cao family held—over three generations and four appointments—the prestigious post of Jiangning Imperial Weaving Superintendent. This position, entrusted only to those close to the emperor, was responsible for producing and procuring textiles and items required by the imperial household, including the silk robes for the *Dragon Canon*.

These unique life experiences profoundly shaped Cao Xueqin. The refined poetry, elegant musical compositions, and exquisite descriptions of objects found throughout *Dream of the Red Chamber* reflect the cultural richness and material sophistication inherited from his family background.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Memorial to the Throne by Cao Yin, Superintendent of the Jiangning Imperial Weaving Office: A horizontal scroll composed mainly of written text. Black characters arranged vertically from right to left dominate the composition. A column of red ink text appears beside them, with a small red seal stamped at the far left. The layout is simple with generous blank space.

sign_language.name: Illustrated Poems of *Dream of the Red Chamber*
sign_language.description:
Written by Gai Qi, Qing dynasty
Illustrated woodblock-printed book, published in the 5th year of the Guangxu reign (1879)
National Palace Museum catalog nos. 003571—003574
Height: 22.5 cm; Width: 15 cm

Much about Cao Xueqin remains shrouded in mystery. After the Cao family fell from power and its property was confiscated, Cao Xueqin—overwhelmed by sorrow—returned to Beijing. In 1762, on New Year's Eve of the renwu year (the 27th year of the Qianlong reign), he passed away “before reaching the age of fifty, his tears exhausted while the book remained unfinished.” Our understanding of his short life and his incomplete *Dream of the Red Chamber* is often fragmentary, as if his very existence were a riddle.

Yet the novel’s unfinished state has never diminished its allure. If anything, its open-endedness inspired generations of readers, giving rise to numerous editions, commentaries, and pictorial interpretations such as this illustrated work.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Illustrated Poems of Dream of the Red Chamber: A book cover design featuring a fine-line drawing of two figures in traditional attire standing beside a large rock. To the right runs a vertical title strip with black characters framed by decorative triangular corners. The layout clearly separates the illustration on the left from the title panel on the right.

sign_language.name: Gold Headdress Finial Set with Eastern Pearls and Cat’s-Eye Stone for an Imperial Consort, Qing dynasty, Qianlong reign
sign_language.description:
NPM collection no. 4837
Height: 16 cm; Base diameter: 4.8 cm

Yuanfei, whose formal name is Jia Yuanchun, is the elder sister of Jia Baoyu. Entering the palace at the age of thirteen or fourteen, she later rose to the rank of Imperial Consort, bringing the Jia family to the height of its glory. The practice of "returning home to observe filial piety" allowed imperial consorts to leave the palace temporarily to visit their parents and elders. To welcome Yuanchun on such an occasion, the Jia family constructed the Grand View Garden.

The Grand View Garden becomes many things at once: a fleeting paradise where Yuanchun briefly reunites with her family yet remains forever separated from her youth; a secluded world where Baoyu and the young maidens live under the protective shadow of her imperial status; and, ultimately, a lost eden—Cao Xueqin’s elegy for a bygone age of prosperity and tenderness.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Qianlong-period gold headdress finial with layered openwork design; the hemispherical gold base is adorned with intricate patterns, supporting multiple tiers of curled and pierced gold elements in bird and foliage motifs. Set with round Eastern pearls throughout, topped by an oval cat’s-eye gemstone of warm yellow-brown hue.

sign_language.name: Bronze Censer, Vase, and Box with Gui Motifs, Late Ming to Qing dynasty
sign_language.description:
NPM collection nos. 1565, 1820, 1819
Censer height: 15 cm; Vase height: 13.8 cm; Box height: 7.9 cm

A faint thread of fragrance seems to drift through every page of *Dream of the Red Chamber*. Incense is burned not only in grand ceremonies, but also during the Jia household’s daily routines. When the Imperial Consort Yuanchun returns home for her ceremonial visit, lilies are burned in great braziers throughout the Grand View Garden. At family banquets, the Jia clan sets out the elegant trio of censer, vase, and box on the table, using them to burn the imperial “Lily Palace Incense.”

This set of three—censer, incense box, and utensil vase—forms a complete ensemble. The censer is used for burning incense; the box stores incense; and the vase holds tools such as tongs and scoops. Arranged with the censer in the center and the box and vase to either side, the censer takes pride of place. The censer mentioned in the novel, known as the *Wenwang ding*, derives from bronze ritual vessels used in ceremonies honoring King Wen of Zhou. Frequently imitated in the Ming and Qing periods, such archaistic pieces were treasured as refined objects suited to the contemplative atmosphere of the scholar’s studio.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Bronze censer, vase, and box set on a carved wooden stand. The vase at left has a slender neck and holds incense tools; the central tripod censer features gilded surfaces with blue-green geometric bands; and the round lidded box at right displays matching decoration. The three pieces form a ritual-like arrangement reminiscent of traditional incense sets.

sign_language.name: In the Style of the Song: Ru Ware and Ding Ware
sign_language.description:
NPM collection no. 17854
Mouth diameter: 15.7 cm; Height: 3.7 cm

Porcelain used in everyday life throughout *Dream of the Red Chamber* frequently evokes the celebrated kilns of the Song dynasty—Ru ware and Ding ware—as well as renowned imperial kilns of the Ming, such as Xuande and Chenghua. These refined objects embellish both the Jia household and the Grand View Garden. For Cao Xueqin, such elegance was embedded in memory: exquisite antique ceramics, alongside Qing-period archaistic wares, form the backdrop of the world he reimagined.

Ru ware—“as precious as the morning star”—appears repeatedly in the novel in the form of dishes, vases, and flower vessels. Ding ware—“the finest white under heaven”—is likewise present: at Baoyu’s birthday banquet, forty Ding ware dishes are used to serve delicacies and seasonal fruits. Quietly luxurious yet understated, these porcelains leave a lasting impression of the refined daily life they once adorned.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A shallow circular dish coated in a soft bluish-grey glaze. The surface is covered with fine crackle patterns, and the gently rounded rim and neatly carved foot give the piece an elegant, understated presence characteristic of Song-inspired ware.

sign_language.name: Clock | William Carpenter, London (1770–1805) | NPM Collection No. 726
sign_language.description:
This ornate clock features a circular dial with Roman numerals for the hours and Arabic numerals marking the minutes and seconds. Encircled by radiant sunburst ornamentation, the face is protected beneath an oval glass cover. The oval case itself is bordered with petal-like motifs, while the top is embellished with a quiver of arrows, a torch, and fluttering ribbons—classical symbols of enlightenment and refined taste.

Below, scrolling acanthus leaves support the clock, which stands on a two-tiered base: the upper platform rests on four eagle-shaped feet, and the lower tier is adorned with floral designs. On the reverse appears the inscription “Willm Carpenter London,” along with a scale regulating speed—“FASTER,” “1–9,” “SLOWER.” Two original winding keys accompany the piece.

Elegant, intricate, and richly symbolic, the clock reflects the craftsmanship and decorative vocabulary of late eighteenth-century London, embodying both precision timekeeping and the aesthetic ideals of its age.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: An ornate gold-colored mantel clock with an oval case. The white dial displays Roman numerals and is surrounded by sunburst rays. Decorative motifs—including ribbons, foliage, and scrolls—adorn the top and base, which rests on intricately formed feet. The overall design is lavish and highly detailed.

sign_language.name: Porcelain Sugar Bowl | Sèvres Manufactory, France, 1783
sign_language.description:
This luminous sugar bowl—its white glaze adorned with delicate gold decoration—bears traces of a long and distinguished journey. On its underside remain both the Sèvres factory marks and an original retail label, preserving the story of how it was made, sold, and eventually carried across continents.

At the center of its marks is the pair of crossed “L”s, the emblem used by the Sèvres manufactory in honor of the French kings Louis XIV and Louis XV. Inside the intertwined letters appears a small double “f,” a date letter indicating the year of manufacture. By comparing this mark to factory records, the bowl can be firmly dated to 1783—placing it within the reign of Louis XV, as the crossed “L”s here suggest.

In its early years Sèvres could produce only soft-paste porcelain, but by the 1770s the factory had finally mastered hard-paste—considered in Europe the equal of prized Chinese porcelain. The gilded crown painted above the mark is the factory’s proud signifier of true hard-paste ware. The initials “LF” at the bottom identify the decorator, the skilled painter La France, who in the spring of 1783 embellished not only this bowl but also matching teapots, milk jugs, and cups with the same refined motifs.

During the latter half of the eighteenth century, Sèvres was overseen by France’s prime minister, Henry Leonard Jean-Baptiste Bertin, a statesman deeply fascinated by distant China. Hoping to express goodwill toward the Qianlong Emperor, Bertin purchased this sugar bowl for 18 livres and arranged for it to be delivered across great distance to the Qing court. The surviving retail label—still legible today—quietly preserves this once-forgotten story of diplomacy, craftsmanship, and the global travels of a single porcelain piece.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A white porcelain sugar bowl decorated with fine gilded floral patterns. The rounded body and matching lid are accented with gold detailing, including a small gilded knop at the top. Elegant, restrained, and luminous in contrast between white glaze and gold lines.

sign_language.name: Gilt-Mounted Glass Perfume Bottle | London, ca. 1760
sign_language.description:
This elongated, flat-sided perfume bottle is crafted from cut glass and encased in a frame of gilt metal adorned with swirling foliate scrolls. It features an inner glass stopper and an outer screw-on cap richly decorated with chased floral patterns. Along the rim of the lid, a line of white enamel bears a tender French inscription in gold: “VOTRE AMITIÉ EN RETOUR” — “Your friendship in return.”

Such bottles, celebrated for their abundance of curves and ornate gilt mounts, were fashionable luxury objects in London during the reign of King George III. Portable, intimate, and decorative, they were often exchanged as refined tokens of affection or friendship, carrying not only fragrance but also sentiment.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A flat, elongated glass bottle encased in ornate gilt metalwork. The golden framework forms scrolls, leaves, and lattice-like patterns around the transparent body. The cap is domed and richly decorated, with a small ribbon-like collar encircling the neck. The object appears delicate, intricate, and highly decorative.

sign_language.name: Folding Magnifier | England, ca. 1760–1770
sign_language.description:
This European-made folding magnifier features a pair of circular lenses that open outward from both sides. The handle is framed with gilt metal carved in flowing floral scrolls, while the central panel is set with polished agate, giving the piece both color and weight. The pierced gold ornamentation reflects the dynamic, symmetrical rhythms of the Baroque style, making this small optical tool as decorative as it is functional.

Such handheld magnifiers were often carried as fashionable accessories in the eighteenth century—objects that blended refinement, curiosity, and the pleasure of close looking.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A slender decorative magnifier with a circular frame at the top and a teardrop-shaped handle below. The handle is filled with a deep blue panel beneath an intricate gilt openwork design of leaves and scrolls. The overall form is elegant, elongated, and richly adorned.

sign_language.name: Gilt-Mounted Agate Snuffbox | Europe, 18th Century
sign_language.description:
This rectangular snuffbox opens from the top, revealing a compartment for powdered tobacco. Both the lid and the box are framed with gilt scrolling acanthus designs, within which slices of moss agate are set like miniature picture panels. At the hinge, silver mounts blossom into tiny leaves set with diamonds, rubies, and emeralds, adding a sparkling flourish to the opening gesture.

The underside is similarly framed with gilt decoration and inset with two agate plaques, each concealing an intimate erotic scene—a hidden luxury common in refined snuffboxes of the period. Comparable to another piece in the Museum attributed to James Cox, this box reflects the exquisite craftsmanship of late eighteenth-century England, where mechanical ingenuity and ornamental artistry often met in objects meant to be held, admired, and treasured.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A small rectangular snuffbox framed in gilt metal. Each side and the lid are inset with translucent agate panels featuring soft cloud-like patterns and silhouettes. Delicate gold scrollwork surrounds each stone panel, and the front edge is embellished with a row of small jewels. The box appears symmetrical, refined, and luxurious in detail.

sign_language.name: Dressing Case | Europe, 18th Century | NPM Enameled Ware 000902
sign_language.description: This compact dressing case assembles a miniature set of personal grooming tools designed for travel and daily refinement. Such cases typically contain a small mirror, glass bottles for perfumes or aromatic powders, and implements such as knives, scissors, and tweezers. The exterior is often lavishly decorated—its panels inlaid with painted enamel plaques, mother-of-pearl, agate, or multicolored gemstones—capturing the opulent aesthetic of eighteenth-century European craftsmanship. Portable yet sumptuous, these cases reflect a world in which elegance accompanied every gesture, even those performed in private.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A small rectangular European dressing case decorated with painted enamel panels featuring flowers and foliage. The box is framed with gilt metal mounts and rests on four tiny feet. A curved gilt handle rises elegantly from the lid, giving the piece a refined and decorative appearance.

sign_language.name: Enamel Perfume Bottle | Europe, 18th Century | NPM Enamel Ware 94
sign_language.description: Shaped like a small vase, this perfume bottle is fitted with a gilded, intricately carved lid topped with applied porcelain flowers. Petal-like bands encircle the upper and lower sections of the body. Against a soft pink enamel ground, two oval reserves present charming scenes of playful children, created using transfer-print techniques. Garlanded ribbons further embellish the surface. In its form, enameling style, and finely worked gilt details, the piece reflects the characteristics of English craftsmanship from the latter half of the eighteenth century.

audio_description.name: Tang Dynasty: Sancai Polo Lady Figurine
audio_description.description: During the Tang dynasty, women admired a healthy and active appearance. They often wore narrow-sleeved jackets with turned-down collars and soft boots—light and practical outfits suitable for various equestrian activities. Polo, introduced from Persia, was especially popular among the upper classes of Tang society, and many tombs have yielded painted pottery or sancai figurines depicting polo players. This piece portrays a fashionable lady engaged in a polo match. She turns her torso to the side, her head leaning slightly forward. Her left hand is raised near the horse’s head as if holding the reins, while her right arm bends as though grasping a stick to strike the ball. A vivid red pigment remains on her chest, indicating the use of precious coloring materials.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Dynasty Sancai Polo Lady Figurine: A ceramic sculpture of a mounted female rider. The composition is balanced, with dominant hues of yellow, green, and brown. The horse stands firmly with legs apart and head slightly lowered. The rider sits upright at the center, with a high coiffed hairstyle and hands positioned as if holding reins. The flowing sancai glazes create a glossy surface, giving the figure a calm and steady presence.

audio_description.name: Tang Dynasty: Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine
audio_description.description: Among the mingqi figurines buried as tomb objects in the Tang dynasty, the well-known “Tang sancai” is only one category. Even more numerous—and produced over a longer period—were various types of painted earthenware figurines. These figures were typically molded using red or gray clay, refined by hand, fired in a kiln, and then decorated with painted pigments. In the case of this lady figurine, the piece was first shaped and fired in gray clay, then coated with a layer of white slip, on top of which red, green, black, and other pigments were applied. Unfortunately, most of the original vibrant colors have flaked away over time, leaving only faint traces of its once-brilliant appearance. The National Palace Museum holds two Tang painted gray-earthenware lady figurines (the other catalogued as Gift Porcelain 000550), both made in the Chang’an region during the eighth century and offering a glimpse into contemporary life. Noblewomen in mid-eighth-century Chang’an were characterized by full, rounded faces and elaborate hairstyles extending outward like cicada wings. Their figures were plump and graceful. They wore open-collared jackets and long skirts that grazed the ground, with the pointed tips of embroidered shoes peeking out from beneath. Although the skirt is voluminous, the draping folds of the sleeves and the gathered fabric between the feet reveal the soft, rounded form of the body beneath, fully expressing the elegant confidence and majestic beauty associated with women of the High Tang period.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine: A standing ceramic female figure. She stands upright with arms lowered naturally, one hand slightly raised, her long sleeves forming gentle curves. She wears a long robe with vertical folds falling from the shoulders. Her face is full and rounded with simply defined features and a calm expression. The symmetrical high coiffure is neatly arranged. The overall surface shows a soft, earthy tone with signs of age.

medias.alt_text: Tang Painted Gray-Earthenware Lady Figurine

audio_description.name: Tang Dynasty — Xing Kiln White-Glazed Flask with Strap Loops
audio_description.description: This white-glazed flask imitates the form of water containers made from metal or leather, often used by nomadic peoples. The exterior walls and base are covered in a glossy white glaze, with pooled areas showing a slight bluish tint reminiscent of lake water. The glaze inside the vessel covers less than half, revealing the grayish-white clay body beneath. The vessel features a flared round mouth, short neck, ring foot, and a long cylindrical body with slightly indented sides. Pairs of strap loops are attached to the upper and lower sections, allowing cords to pass through—much like flasks carried on horseback. During the Tang dynasty, objects made from different materials often imitated one another. Another example in the museum’s collection is a white-glazed molded cup with fish motifs, shaped like a four-petaled flower, which derives from the multi-lobed metal drinking cups of the Sasanian tradition.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Tang Dynasty — Xing Kiln White-Glazed Flask with Strap Loops: A smooth, unpainted white ceramic flask. The body is slightly elongated and cylindrical, narrowing toward the top with gently flaring shoulders. The mouth is wide with a simple outward-curving rim. Small, understated strap loops are attached to the upper and lower sections. The flask has a clean, elegant silhouette with a soft white sheen.

audio_description.name: Five Dynasties — Yue Ware Secret-Color Celadon Basin
audio_description.description: This celadon basin features an outward-flaring rim with a folded edge, a slanted curved wall, deep rounded belly, and a flat base. The center of the underside is slightly concave, and firing marks remain clearly visible along the footring, where the unglazed areas reveal the gray clay body. The piece is covered in a translucent celadon glaze of grayish-green tone. The glaze is thin and evenly applied, with a few pale speckled patches on the outer wall. Before archaeological discoveries in the early Republic of China period clarified kiln attributions, experts from the Qing Court Aftercare Committee mistakenly identified this piece as a Ru ware product and inscribed inside the basin: “One Ru ware flared-rim fruit wash.” This inscription reflects how historical and modern approaches to ceramic connoisseurship may differ. The museum’s Yue ware ‘secret-color’ celadon basin is finely glazed, elegant in form, and closely resembles celadon basins unearthed from Five Dynasties tombs, suggesting it may have been used by members of the upper class during that period.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Five Dynasties — Yue Ware Secret-Color Celadon Basin: A shallow ceramic basin with a wide circular opening. The rim flares gently outward with smooth edges. Covered in a soft greenish celadon glaze, the surface is even with subtle natural speckling. The body tapers downward toward a smaller flat base, giving the vessel a simple and composed appearance.

audio_description.name: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Baby Pillow
audio_description.description: This white-glazed ceramic pillow shaped as a reclining infant exemplifies the refined modeling and decorative techniques of Ding ware. Ding kilns primarily produced white porcelains noted for their precise craftsmanship, smooth and lustrous glaze, and ivory-tinged color. Decorative methods included shallow carving, deep engraving, and molded designs. On this pillow, the creamy white glaze appears warm and mellow. The head and body were each formed in two joined halves, assembled together, and then finely carved to define the facial features. Various decorative techniques were skillfully combined: the floral motifs along the hem of the long garment, the spherical patterns on the vest, and the cloud-and-chilong designs on the platform are all rendered through molding, while the peony scrolls on the back are carved. The molded patterns are crisp, and the carved lines flow naturally, achieving a harmonious balance. On the underside is an imperial poem composed by the Qianlong Emperor, in which he likens such pillows to ‘warning pillows’—objects reminding him to remain diligent. When read together with other imperial poems on Ding ware child pillows, it also reveals his wish, like King Wu Ding in ancient times, to find virtuous ministers through dreams. Only three surviving examples of this baby-pillow form are known today, two housed in this museum and the third in the Palace Museum, Beijing.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Baby Pillow: A ceramic figure of an infant lying sideways on a rectangular platform. The child lifts its head slightly, with both hands resting beneath the cheek. The rounded face shows a calm, gentle smile. The clothing bears delicate patterns, with folds and motifs clearly rendered. The glaze is soft and pale, with a smooth, ivory-white sheen.

audio_description.name: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Meiping with Incised Lotus Design
audio_description.description: This meiping vase features a small mouth with a rounded lip, a short neck, high rounded shoulders, and an elongated body that tapers gracefully downward before flaring slightly near the base. The recessed base forms a ring foot. The vessel is decorated with incised motifs. Short, oval lotus petals are arranged in rows around the upper section, while the lower section features slender, elongated petals outlined with double incised lines. At the center of the body, front and back, appear sprays of branching lotus blossoms, accompanied on each side by simple outlines of lotus leaves. The entire vase is covered in an ivory-white glaze that drips lightly in places, forming characteristic tear marks. The footrim is left unglazed.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Northern Song — Ding Ware White-Glazed Meiping with Incised Lotus Design: A tall white porcelain vase with a gently curving silhouette that tapers toward the base. The small flared mouth and short neck lead into rounded shoulders. Fine incised patterns, including leaf and scrolling motifs, cover the surface without protruding. The glaze is soft and creamy white, giving the vase an elegant, elongated form.

audio_description.name: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Zun with String-Pattern Decoration
audio_description.description: This vessel features a cylindrical body with straight sides, an inner rim forming a raised lip, deep vertical walls, and three beast-shaped feet left unglazed on the underside. The form is stately and balanced, with a rich bluish-green glaze characteristic of Guan ware. The dense network of crackles appears in layered patterns, while the shape itself derives from earlier Northern Song forms seen in Ru and Ding ware zun vessels with string-pattern bands. The broad and flat base bears twelve large spur marks revealing the dark gray clay body beneath. The exterior wall is decorated with three tiers of string patterns, each composed of three horizontal raised lines. The entire piece is coated in a thick, lustrous pale blue glaze. Where the glaze pools and thins around the ridges, the string-pattern relief appears slightly darkened in brownish tones. Along the rim, the thinner glaze reveals subtle reddish-brown hues. The surface is covered in intricate, ice-crackle patterns. Similar fragments have been unearthed at the Jiaotanxia and Laohudong Guan kiln sites in Hangzhou, Zhejiang.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Zun with String-Pattern Decoration: A circular vessel shown upside down. The pale celadon glaze displays dense crackle patterns. Multiple pronounced spur marks appear across the base, in dark brown tones. Three short supporting feet of matching glaze emerge around the edge, giving the object a stable, disc-like appearance.

audio_description.name: Southern Song — Guan Ware Celadon Vase with Tube Handles
audio_description.description: This vase features a slightly flared round mouth, a short neck, and a pair of tubular handles attached symmetrically to the shoulders. The body is full and rounded, tapering to a flat base supported by a low ring foot. Two raised string lines encircle the neck. The clay body is thick and substantial, and the entire vessel is coated in a rich celadon glaze. The surface is covered with fine crackle lines in pale brown tones, with occasional tiny pinholes. The edge of the ring foot reveals the unglazed clay body, brushed with an iron-brown slip.

The overall shape is harmonious and understated.
